item.title: Unrest Spreads to More Cities in Ukraine
item.description: President Viktor F. Yanukovych and antigovernment demonstrators remain at an impasse in Kiev, as the protesters’ demands have grown.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Orthodox priests pray as they stand between protesters and the police in Kiev early Friday.

item.title: India Ink: The Journey of ‘Miss Lovely’ from Cannes to the Censors
item.description: The director Ashim Ahluwalia said he never thought his movie about the sex-horror film industry of 1980s Mumbai would get past the Indian review board, much less draw an enthusiastic response from local audiences.
item.dc:creator: By RAKSHA KUMAR
item.media:description: Actress Niharika Singh in a still from the film 'Miss Lovely'.

item.title: Deadly Cairo Bomb Attacks Raise Fears of New Insurgency
item.description: The blasts took place despite intensified security measures ahead of the third anniversary of the 2011 Arab Spring revolt.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Argentina Eases Currency Controls, but Citizens Are Not Reassured
item.description: The government’s unexpected action, intended to reduce anxiety about the rapid decline in the peso’s value, instead added to a sense of crisis.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO and WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Shulamit Aloni, Outspoken Israeli Lawmaker, Dies at 86
item.description: Mrs. Aloni was an early champion of civil liberties, challenger of religious hegemony, and outspoken opponent of Israel’s occupation of the Palestinian territories.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: David Rubinger/Time Life Pictures, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Shulamit Aloni, then education minister, talking to students in 1992.

item.title: Former Times Interpreter Killed in Afghanistan
item.description: The former interpreter, Noor Ahmad Noori, was found beaten, stabbed and possibly suffocated on a roadside near Lashkar Gah, where he lived.
item.dc:creator: By TAIMOOR SHAH and ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Russia Plans to Extend Snowden Asylum, Lawmaker Says
item.description: The lawmaker hinted that the extension of temporary refugee status for the former National Security Agency contractor might be indefinite.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

item.title: 2 Sides in Syria Talks Agree to Meet, Averting a Breakdown
item.description: The agreement came as the Syrian government delegation was threatening to walk out of the Geneva talks unless “serious” progress was made quickly.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Members of the Syrian opposition coalition arriving for a meeting with the United Nations special envoy, Lakhdar Brahimi, in Geneva, Switzerland, on Friday.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: January 24
item.description: Indian tennis player Sania Mirza during a mixed doubles semi final match at the Australian Open tournament in Melbourne.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Sania Mirza, Indian tennis player, hitting a shot during her mixed doubles semi-final match with Romanian partner Horia Tecau against Jarmila Gajdosova of Australia and Matthew Ebden at the Australian Open tournament in Melbourne.

item.title: Number of Darfur’s Displaced Surged in 2013
item.description: A report by the top United Nations peacekeeping official to the Security Council presented a pessimistic picture of the decade-old Darfur conflict.
item.category: United Nations Department of Peacekeeping Operations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Defying Economy, Chinese Hit the Road
item.description: While Hong Kong continues to shine for mainland Chinese shoppers, travelers are venturing farther and leaving deeper economic tracks.
item.dc:creator: By BETTINA WASSENER
item.media:description: Mainland Chinese tourists line up outside a Prada store in the Tsim Sha Tsui district of Hong Kong.

item.title: U.N. Sounds Alarm as Iraqis Flee Violence
item.description: The number of people fleeing their homes in Anbar Province is bigger than at the height of sectarian violence years ago, the United Nations said.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: DealBook: Geopolitical Tensions Fly During Panel on American Interests
item.description: Syria, the Iraq war and other trouble spots were hot-button issues in a panel that included Senator John McCain, the Republican from Arizona, and Aleksei K. Pushkov, the head of Russia’s parliamentary Foreign Affairs Committee.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL J. DE LA MERCED
item.media:description: Senator John McCain at a session on Friday at the World Economic Forum.

item.title: In U-Turn, North Korea Agrees to Family Reunions
item.description: The North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, called for improved ties in his New Year’s Day speech. His country has repeated the offer almost daily since.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Thai Court Says Postponement of Election Is Constitutional
item.description: The ruling surprised scholars and was seen as a setback for Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra, the target of protesters who want to stop the vote.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: India Ink: New Law to Ban Manual Removal of Human Waste Disappoints
item.description: India enacted its most stringent law yet against the dehumanizing task known as manual scavenging, which is exclusively done by Dalits, but human rights activists say the law has no teeth.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By MAX BEARAK
item.media:description: Former manual scavengers burning baskets used to collect human waste at a rally in Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh, on Nov. 30, 2012.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Shanghai Test Scores and the Mystery of the Missing Children
item.description: China’s restrictions on internal migration serve to drive migrant children out of the city as early as primary school, statistics show, and critics say that skews testing results indicating its education system’s equity and superiority.
item.category: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development
item.dc:creator: By HELEN GAO
item.media:credit: Ariana Lindquist for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pupils line up at a Shanghai school for children of migrant workers. Some have questioned whether migrants are fairly represented in Shanghai test results.

item.title: At Least 5 Killed as 3 Bombs Go Off in Cairo
item.description: The explosions struck as Egypt was on high alert ahead of the third anniversary of the Jan. 25 start of the 2011 uprising.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Planet Hillary
item.description: The gravitational pull of a possible 2016 campaign is bringing all the old Clinton characters into her orbit. Can she make the stars align, or will chaos prevail?
item.dc:creator: By AMY CHOZICK
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Jesse Lenz; Hillary Clinton: Stan Honda/AFP/Getty Images. Black Hole: M. Weiss/NASA. Nebula: M. Livio/ESA/NASA. Dark Matter, Vortex and Supernova: NASA. Cluster: Karel Teuwen. Quasar: ESA/NASA. Comet: ESA.

item.title: U.N. Says Muslims Were Massacred in Tense Myanmar Region
item.description: Human rights groups say that with this latest round of anti-Muslim violence, Myanmar’s government appears to be trying to cover up the problem.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: India Ink: Raid in Delhi Neighborhood Rattles African Residents
item.description: Finding themselves under increased scrutiny, many residents of Khirki Extension were fearful about talking about the way they have been treated during their stay in India.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Claims of Police Brutality in Ukraine Amid Talks to Quell Unrest
item.description: As negotiations went on between opposition leaders and the president of Ukraine, a video surfaced of Berkut riot police officers stripping a protester naked.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Protesters clashed with police on Thursday in central Kiev.

item.title: World Briefing: Deadly Fire at a Nursing Home in Canada
item.description: The fire in Quebec killed at least five people and left 30 missing, all of them believed to be 80 or older and many with limited mobility.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: World Briefing: Al Qaeda Calls for Rebel Unity in Syria
item.description: In an audio recording released Thursday, the leader of Al Qaeda called on Islamist brigades in northern Syria to stop fighting one another.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Japan’s Leader Compares Strain With China to Germany and Britain in 1914
item.description: The blunt remarks, which concurred with others made recently by prominent historians, provoked an angry response from Beijing.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
